title: CR/LF Issue (I Think)
body:
In Windows 10, either in:

```
VIM - Vi IMproved 7.4 (2013 Aug 10, compiled Aug 10 2013 14:33:40)
MS-Windows 32-bit console version
Compiled by mool@tororo
```

or Visual Studio 2015 4.6.0.138 if I _type_ the following:

```
use std::thread;

fn main() {
    let handle = thread::spawn(|| {
        "Hello from a thread!"
    });

    println!("{}", handle.join().unwrap());
}
```

I get:

```
------ Rebuild All started: Project: thread_test, Configuration: Debug default ------
src\main.rs(8,20): error E0277: the trait `core::fmt::Display` is not implemented for the type `()`
<std macros>(2,25): warning : note: expansion site
<std macros>(1,1): warning : note: in expansion of print!
<std macros>(3,1): warning : note: expansion site
<std macros>(1,1): warning : note: in expansion of println!
src\main.rs(8,5): warning : note: expansion site
src\main.rs(8,20): error : run `rustc --explain E0277` to see a detailed explanation
note: `()` cannot be formatted with the default formatter; try using `:?` instead if you are using a format string
<std macros>(2,25): warning : note: expansion site
<std macros>(1,1): warning : note: in expansion of print!
<std macros>(3,1): warning : note: expansion site
<std macros>(1,1): warning : note: in expansion of println!
src\main.rs(8,5): warning : note: expansion site
Done building project "thread_test.rsproj" -- FAILED.

Build FAILED.
========== Rebuild All: 0 succeeded, 1 failed, 0 skipped ==========
```

BUT if I copy and paste it from "https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/concurrency.html" it will compile.

I can only think that either:
- Windows line endings are confusing the lexer; or
- Perhaps tabs?

I'm hedging my bets on line endings at the moment.

Rust version:

```
rustc 1.5.0 (3d7cd77e4 2015-12-04)
```
